abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, in terms of its contribution to poverty
            alleviation, and increased food security, and,
            sustainability is likely, although expansion of communal
            irrigation will require stronger local government
            units' (LGUs) commitment. The many lessons convey
            mainly, that small-scale communal irrigation schemes are
            cost effective, economically viable, and, may contribute to
            poverty alleviation, thus, providing communal responsibility
            is an effective way to ensure sustainable irrigation. But,
            successful communal irrigation require clear guidelines on
            the roles, and responsibilities of each stakeholder,
            including a comprehensive institution building program.
            There is the need for a national-level agreement among LGUs,
            central agencies, and the National Irrigation Administration
            - regarding financing arrangements, in particular, and, the
            respective roles, including design, construction, and,
            operation and maintenance (O&M) to be clearly defined.
            In addition, the need to implement a self-sustaining system
            for operation and maintenance, is paramount, to avoid
            dependency on Government funds. Hence, the establishment of
            earmarked O&M funds, financed from the Irrigators
            Associations' share of service fee collection, and,
            trust funds, financed from amortization payments by communal
            schemes, should be seriously considered for sustained
            communal irrigation.
